overview.title: Turn Structure
overview.description: Every turn in Magic follows a structured sequence of phases and steps. Understanding this timing is crucial for knowing when you can cast spells and use abilities.
overview.importance: Turn structure determines when players can take actions, when abilities trigger, and how the game flows from one decision point to the next.

turnOrder.explanation: Players take turns in a predetermined order, with each player being the 'active player' during their turn.
turnOrder.activePlayer: The player whose turn it is. They make decisions first when multiple things happen simultaneously.
turnOrder.nonActivePlayer: All other players. They respond to the active player's actions and make decisions in turn order.

beginning.name: Beginning Phase
beginning.description: The start of your turn where you untap, handle upkeep effects, and draw your card for the turn.
beginning.purpose: Resets your permanents and gives you new resources

untap.name: Untap Step
untap.description: You untap all your tapped permanents. No player can cast spells or activate abilities during this step.
rules: All permanents you control that are tapped become untapped
This happens automatically - you don't choose what to untap
No player receives priority during this step
No spells or abilities can be cast or activated
strategicNotes: Plan ahead - consider what you'll need tapped vs untapped
Some permanents enter tapped and won't untap this turn
Vigilance creatures don't tap when attacking

upkeep.name: Upkeep Step
upkeep.description: Triggered abilities that happen 'at the beginning of your upkeep' trigger. Players can cast spells and activate abilities.
rules: Upkeep triggers go on the stack
Active player receives priority first
Players can cast instants and activate abilities
Good time for instant-speed setup
strategicNotes: Pay any required upkeep costs or sacrifice permanents
Good time to use instant-speed effects
Some players use this to bluff having instant responses

draw.name: Draw Step
draw.description: You draw one card from your library. This is not optional. Players can respond after the draw.
rules: You must draw a card if able
If your library is empty, you lose the game
The draw uses the stack - players can respond
Some effects can replace or modify this draw
strategicNotes: This is guaranteed card advantage each turn
Plan your hand size for maximum hand size (usually 7)
Some cards care about the first card drawn each turn

main1.name: First Main Phase
main1.description: Your main opportunity to cast sorcery-speed spells before combat. You can play a land, cast creatures, and set up for combat.
main1.purpose: Deploy threats and resources before combat
whatYouCanDo: Cast sorcery-speed spells (creatures, sorceries, planeswalkers, artefacts, enchantments)
Cast instants and activate instant-speed abilities
strategicConsiderations: Deploy creatures that can attack this turn
Consider what you want to hold for post-combat
Think about instant-speed responses you might need
Evaluate whether to play lands now or save them
main1.timing: Sorcery speed - stack must be empty and you must have priority

combat.name: Combat Phase
combat.description: The phase where creatures attack and combat damage is dealt. Consists of five distinct steps with multiple opportunities for interaction.
combat.purpose: Primary method of reducing opponent's life total and pressuring planeswalkers

beginningOfCombat.name: Beginning of Combat Step
beginningOfCombat.description: Combat officially begins. Triggered abilities that happen 'at the beginning of combat' trigger.
rules: Combat begins - no attackers declared yet
Triggered abilities go on the stack
Last chance to act before attackers are declared
Both players can cast spells and activate abilities

declareAttackers.name: Declare Attackers Step
declareAttackers.description: Active player chooses which creatures attack and what they're attacking (players or planeswalkers).
rules: Declare all attackers simultaneously
Attacking creatures become tapped (unless vigilance)
Choose what each attacker is attacking
Attack triggers go on the stack
restrictions: Creatures with summoning sickness can't attack
Must be able to legally attack chosen target
strategicNotes: Think about which creatures you need for defence
Attacking planeswalkers can be strategically important

declareBlockers.name: Declare Blockers Step
declareBlockers.description: Defending player chooses which creatures block attacking creatures.
rules: Declare all blockers simultaneously
Each blocker can block exactly one attacker
Multiple creatures can block the same attacker
Block triggers go on the stack
restrictions: Flying creatures can only be blocked by flying/reach
Once blocked, attacker stays blocked even if blocker leaves
strategicConsiderations: Sometimes taking damage is better than losing creatures
Multiple small blockers can take down large threats

combatDamage.name: Combat Damage Step
combatDamage.description: Creatures deal damage simultaneously. This is when most creatures die in combat.
rules: All combat damage assigned and dealt simultaneously
Creatures deal damage equal to their power
Unblocked attackers damage defending player/planeswalker
Lethal damage destroys creatures
specialRules: First strike creates additional damage step before this one
Double strike deals damage in both first strike and regular steps
Deathtouch makes any amount of damage lethal
Trample assigns excess damage to defending player
damageAssignment: Attacking player chooses damage assignment order for multiple blockers
Must assign lethal damage before assigning to next creature
Trample damage spills over to defending player
Lifelink causes damage to gain you life

endOfCombat.name: End of Combat Step
endOfCombat.description: Combat officially ends. Last chance for combat-related effects.
rules: End of combat triggers go on the stack
Creatures stop being attacking and blocking
Players can cast spells and activate abilities
'Until end of combat' effects end
strategicUse: Some creatures have end of combat triggers
Last chance for combat-related instant effects
Good timing for some removal spells

main2.name: Second Main Phase
main2.description: Another main phase after combat. You can do anything you could do in the first main phase.
main2.purpose: Deploy threats that couldn't attack anyway, or hold up mana for instant responses
strategicDifferences: Creatures played now have summoning sickness
You know the results of combat
Opponent knows what resources you have left
Good for playing cards you don't need immediately
commonActions: Play a land if you didn't earlier
Cast creatures that can't attack this turn anyway
Cast sorcery-speed spells you held back

ending.name: Ending Phase
ending.description: The conclusion of your turn where end-of-turn effects happen and cleanup occurs.
ending.purpose: Wrap up the turn and prepare for the next player

end.name: End Step
end.description: Triggered abilities that happen 'at the beginning of the end step' or 'at end of turn' trigger.
rules: End of turn triggers go on the stack
Players can cast spells and activate abilities
Many temporary effects end here
Common time for opponent to act
strategicNotes: Good time to activate abilities before turn ends
Some effects specifically wait for this step

cleanup.name: Cleanup Step
cleanup.description: Automatic cleanup happens with no player interaction, unless triggered abilities are created.
automaticActions: Discard down to maximum hand size (usually 7)
End all 'until end of turn' effects
rules: No player receives priority normally
If triggered abilities are created, players get priority
Additional cleanup steps occur if needed
Turn doesn't end until cleanup completes with no triggers
specialCases: Madness triggers can happen from discarding to hand size
Some permanents trigger when 'until end of turn' effects end
Multiple cleanup steps possible if triggers keep happening

priority.definition: The right to cast spells or activate abilities
rules: Active player receives priority first in each step/phase
Players must pass priority for game to advance
When all players pass priority in succession, top spell/ability resolves
Players can respond to spells and abilities before they resolve

sorcerySpeed.when: Main phases only, when stack is empty, when you have priority

commonMistakes: Trying to cast sorceries during opponent's turn
Forgetting about the cleanup step for hand size
Not understanding when creatures can attack
Forgetting damage is removed during cleanup
Not realizing when you have/don't have priority

practicalTips: Always untap everything unless an effect says otherwise
Use your upkeep step for instant-speed setup
Plan your main phases - deploy threats in main 1, utility in main 2
Combat has five steps - each allows responses
Save instant-speed responses for opponent's end step when possible
Remember cleanup step removes damage and temporary effects
Don't rush - each phase has strategic importance
Priority passes are how the game advances - learn the timing
